metadata.title: Charging performance evaluation of finned conical thermal storage system encapsulated with nano-enhanced phase change material

sections.text:

Research Paper
Charging performance evaluation of finned conical thermal storage system encapsulated with nano-enhanced phase change material Rupinder Pal Singha,b, Haoxin Xuc, S.C. Kaushikb, Dibakar Rakshitb, Alessandro Romagnolic,⁎
a Energy Research Institute @ NTU, Nanyang Technological University, 1 Cleantech Loop, 06-04 Cleantech One, Singapore 637141, Singapore b Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, 110016, India c School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore
H I G H L I G H T S
• Metal and metal oxide nanoparticles are compared with a carbon based nanoparticle.• Nano-enhanced PCM ranking methodology is proposed.• Novel conical shaped storage system with fins and graphene nano plates is studied.• Fins provide better heat transfer enhancement than the nanoparticles dispersions.• Reduction of 57% in melting time is observed.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Charging performance evaluation Latent heat storage system Natural convection Nanoparticles Fins
A B S T R A C T
This study introduces a novel latent heat storage system using a combination of active (fins and nanoparticles) and passive (conical design) heat transfer enhancement techniques for the solar absorption chilling system. First part of the work proposes a selection criterion using Multi-attribute decision making (MADM) combined with Multi objectives decision making (MODM) tools to rank and select the different nanoparticles. The methodology suggests Graphene as the best candidate amongst the widely used metal (Cu, Al, Ni, Ag) and metal oxide (CuO, Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2) nanoparticles. Subsequently, the charging performance of the medium temperature eutectic salt (LiNO3-KCl; 50:50) dispersed with graphene nanoplates is studied in a conical shaped shell and tube storage system with & without fins. The numerical investigations are performed using the actual plant data of double effect solar absorption system. Based on the plant operating conditions, the Stefan and Grashoff numbers are obtained as 0.35 & 4.2 × 105 respectively, showing the laminar flow of molten PCM. The thermal performance of the storage system coupled with heat transfer and fluid flow is studied for melt fraction, temperature field, the energy stored and heat flux variations at different concentration of graphene. Effect of enhanced viscosity and reduction in natural convection heat transfer due to GNP dispersion is studied simultaneously with the gained advantage of increased thermal conductivity. It is concluded that melting time is reduced by 57% using the proposed storage design in comparison with a conventional cylindrical system.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Energy storage technologies play a significant role in bridging the gap between the demand and supply, particularly for intermittent renewable energy systems like solar and wind. These technologies are classified as sensible, latent and thermochemical. Out of these, latent heat storage system (LHSS) is capable of storing/releasing a large quantity of heat at nearly isothermal conditions. LHSS uses Phase change material (PCM) which are able to store 5–14 times more
thermal energy than a sensible heat storage material [1]. LHSS are further categorized as low, medium and high-temperature systems. The thermal storage systems are extensively studied for various low temperature (less than 100 °C) and high-temperature applications (above 250 °C). Most of the high-temperature LHSS are applied to concentrated solar power generation whereas low-temperature PCMs are employed for domestic water heating, cold energy storage, greenhouse heating and buildings storage [2]. However, there are few studies reported on the medium temperature (120–200 °C) thermal storage systems [3].

These systems find their extensive applications in high-temperature solar cooling, organic Rankine cycle, industrial waste heat recovery, district heating networks, and other industrial processes.
In spite of the promising applications, LHSS has an underlying problem of the sluggish heat discharging/charging rates due to their poor thermal conductivity. Literature suggested many methods like heat pipes [45], metal foams [1], cascading [6], fins [7], nano inclusions [8], etc. to improve the overall heat transfer rate. It is established that increasing the heat transfer area through fins is an economical and effective way to enhance the heat transfer rate. However, fins are also responsible for hampering the natural convection currents inside the liquid PCM. Hence, the fin size needs to be optimized for the smooth development of convection currents. In our previous study [9], it is found that fin height up to the half of annular space is the best possible configuration for enhanced rate of heat transfer.
There is also a growing interest in using nanoparticles to enhance the effective thermal conductivity. Various experimental studies on nanoparticles are reported using pure metals [1011], metal oxides [1213] and carbon-based nanoparticles [1415] like graphene, graphite, carbon nanotubes etc. [16]. Amaral et al. [17] reviewed the different carbon nanostructures for thermal storage systems and concluded that graphene nanoplates provide the highest thermal conductivity enhancement. However, nano dispersion raises the overall viscosity and density of nano-PCM composite which severely deteriorates the convection heat transfer. Fan et al. [18] observed a dramatic increase in the viscosity, up to 10 times at 3% GNP dispersion in a low-temperature PCM. Khodadadi et al. [19] presented a comprehensive review of thermal conductivity enhancement using various metal, metal oxide and carbon nanoparticles in thermal storage systems. It was reported that enhanced viscosity due to nano dispersion deteriorates the buoyancy-driven flow and hampers natural convection. So, a tradeoff between the enhanced thermal conductivity and reduced natural convection is required while dispersing nanoparticles.
Most of the studies on the nano-PCM composites are confined to the small quantities inside beakers/test tubes for the material characterization. The experimental testing of various nano-composites is infeasible due to the involvement of excessive cost and time. So, a
systematic and comprehensive study is needed to select and rank the various nano-PCM composites with high statistical accuracy. Moreover, the studies on these composites in a design level heat exchanger are scarce. Only a few designs are proposed using nanoparticles in cylindrical, rectangular or shell-tube design. It is found that shell and tube design provides the minimum charging time [2021] and is used in both horizontal and vertical orientations. However, the vertical orientation of LHSS is preferred due to the higher rate of heat transfer [22]. In a vertical LHSS, natural convection is dominant in the top region causing quick melting [23]. Seddegh et al. [24], proposed a conically shaped storage system which utilizes natural convection more effectively due to the packing of more PCM in the top region. However, only a 12% reduction in melting time was reported using the conically shaped design. The literature review summarizes the following observations for effective system design.
• Employing fins is an economical and effective way to improve the thermal performance of LHSS. However, fins must be of an optimized size so that they don’t hamper the convective flow of molten PCM. • Nanoparticles enhance the effective thermal conductivity of PCM. Nevertheless, nanodispersion increases the effective viscosity and reduces convection heat transfer. • The negative effects of using fins and nanoparticles can be suppressed using an optimized fin with nanoparticles together in a conical shaped LHSS.

It is expected that conical design with other active heat transfer enhancement methods is the solution for faster charging/discharging rates. First time in literature, the present study reports the use of combined passive and active heat transfer enhancement techniques to propose a highly efficient thermal storage system for quick charging rates. The various cases are further investigated and compared; conical shaped LHSS (with and without nanoparticles), conical LHSS (with and without fins), and conical LHSS (with both fins and nanoparticles). The first section of the work proposes a selection criterion using MADM combined with MODM tools to rank the various nanoparticles including metal, metal oxide nanoparticles and graphene nanoplates. Further, the charging performance of the most suitable nanoparticle is studied in a
conical storage system. Dynamic differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) tests are performed to evaluate the specific heat and melting temperature. The conjugate heat transfer in LHSS is studied for the temperature field, liquid fraction, the energy stored and heat flux variations at different concentration of nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2. Assessment of nano-PCM composite for LHSS
sections.text:
Highly thermal conductive nanoparticles are dispersed to the base PCM to improve the thermal performance of the storage system. But, no study is found to provide a comprehensive methodology for assessing and ranking the different nanoparticles. Moreover, using different nanoparticles at the actual design scale would be very expensive and infeasible. Hence, there is a need to develop mathematical tools to rank and predict the thermal performance of nano-PCM composites. The combined MADM and MODM ranking methodology developed for the pure PCM in our previous work [25] is further extended to include the nanoparticles. The methodology evaluates the characteristics of each nano-PCM composite and combines with the performance objectives (thermal diffusivity & energy storage capacity) to rank them comprehensively. A group of widely used metal (Cu, Al, Ni, Ag), metal oxide (CuO, Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2) and carbon-based nanoparticles (Graphene) are investigated for high temperature solar cooling thermal storage system. The effect of nanoparticles on the thermophysical properties of PCM is discussed in the Supplementary section.
The objective is to select and rank the nano-PCM composites according to their thermal performance goals. The thermo-physical properties at various concentration of nanoparticles are evaluated using the homogeneous model theory [26]. The most critical PCM selection criteria are the desired melting temperature, heat storage capacity, thermal conductivity, the degree of supercooling along with economic and chemical aspects, which is used in the pre-screening step. sections.text:

sections.heading: 4.1. Model description and governing equations
sections.text:
The schematic of double effect solar cooling integrated with LHSS is shown in Fig. 4a. The minimum generator temperature should be 140 °C, as per the design conditions of an actual solar absorption chiller [32]. Both active and passive heat transfer enhancement techniques are implemented to improve the charging performance of LHSS. Active heat transfer enhancement methods are defined as techniques which increase the overall material cost of the storage system, such as nanoparticles or fins. However, passive enhancement using conical shaped walls, only change the geometry without increasing the material cost of the storage system. The various numerical models are studied; (a) Cylinder versus conical arrangement (b) Conical LHSS with GNP (c) Conical LHSS with fins (d) Conical LHSS with both fins and GNP. In all the cases, PCM is packed in the vertically oriented annulus as shown in Fig. 4b. The conical design proposed by Seddegh [24] is shown in Fig. 4(c), can be further improved by incorporating fins and GNP for the quick charging/discharging rates.
In the present model, the inner diameter of the cylinder carrying HTF is 50.8 mm. The length of the conical shell is taken as 300 mm. The pipes are made up of stainless steel in which inner pipe (thickness 1.2 mm) is carrying high-temperature HTF, Dynalene-HT [31]. The heat is transported through five annular stainless steel fins fixed on the outer surface of the pipe carrying hot HTF. The optimized thickness and height of the fins are taken as 2.5 mm and 37.5 mm respectively, based on the findings of the previous work [9]. The outer shell is perfectly insulated. The equations governing the fluid flow and melting process are solved numerically with ANSYS Fluent 18.2 [33]. Realizable k-ε turbulence model with standard wall function is used in the present analysis. This model has been validated in various similar shell and tube designs [34,35]. Initially, PCM is in a solid state at a temperature of 145 °C. The assumptions are given as; (1) Air bubble doesn’t exist in the molten PCM. (2) Melted PCM is Newtonian & incompressible. (3) Boussinesq approximation for natural convection is used. (4) Fully developed turbulent flow. (5) The thermal conductivity of PCM is temperature independent. (6) Viscous dissipation is negligible. The numerical model solves the continuity, momentum and energy equation in the relevant domain using the finite volume method. The melting
phenomenon of the PCM is coupled with flowing HTF (hot). Continuity, momentum, and energy conservation equations are as follows:

sections.heading: 4.2. Numerical solution
sections.text: Semi-implicit pressure linked equations (SIMPLE) algorithm is used for the pressure-velocity coupling of the numerical model. PRESTO scheme is implemented for pressure correction. Second order differencing scheme is used to discretize energy and momentum equation. The various grid sizes with 80,689, 99,231 & 112,431 cells are checked to evaluate grid independence. Finally, grid size with 99,231 cells is selected, and further refinement doesn’t show any remarkable improvement in the accuracy of the average liquid fraction. Time step of 0.2 s keeps the solution stable and completely converge the results. Convergence criteria for continuity, momentum, and energy equation are set as 10−4, 10−4 & 10−7 respectively. The under-relaxation factors for momentum, pressure, energy and liquid fraction are set at 0.7, 0.3, 1 and 0.9 respectively.

sections.heading: 4.3. Validation
sections.text:
The developed numerical model is validated against two previous work. Firstly, the model is validated with the experiments work by Akgun et al. [38]. The details are already given in our previous work [9]. The CFD model is further validated with the storage system comprising annular fins, proposed by Yang et al. [39]. The annular fins were fixed on the outer surface of pipe carrying HTF inside a low-temperature PCM. The liquid fraction variation is compared with the developed numerical model as shown in Fig. 5. The root means square deviation and correlation coefficient are calculated as 4.5% and 0.99 respectively. Hence, the numerical model can be well accepted with a high degree of
accuracy.

sections.heading: 5. Results and discussion
sections.text: The total quantity of PCM is 18 kg for all the cases studied to have a judicious comparison. The charging performance LHSS is investigated at GNP volume (%) of 1, 3 & 5 at the fixed Stefan number of 0.35. The fin volume fraction is constant (0.15) for all the cases studied.

sections.heading: 5.1. Heat transfer enhancement using conical shaped LHSS
sections.text:
The contours of the solid-liquid interface for both cylindrical and conical configuration is are shown in Fig. 6. The movement of the melting front initiates from the heated pipe wall and moves radially and axially. The shape of melted PCM is not parallel to heated pipe wall which verifies the presence of natural convection along with heat conduction phenomenon.
During the 1st hour of melting (τ < 1 h), both the arrangements reflect the equal quantity of molten PCM due to dominating conduction heat transfer. The melting interface doesn’t reach the outer adiabatic wall in a conical LHSS due to the increased volume of PCM in the upper region. Afterward (τ > 1 h), more volume of PCM is melted in the conical LHSS due to improved convective heat transfer. The total time taken for complete melting is 475 min and 399 min for cylindrical and conical arrangements respectively, showing a 16% reduction in melting time. It is observed that buoyancy force inside the liquid PCM accelerates the melting phenomenon in the upper region of LHSS. Also, the width of the melted PCM around the heated pipe wall doesn’t show substantial growth (towards the outer shell) in the bottom region. This is because the HTF transfers heat into a thin layer of molten PCM near the heated pipe wall. Heat then transports to the upper section inside liquid PCM through convection. The melting process is little delayed in the lower region due to the higher density of solid PCM. The concept of packing more PCM in the top region (convection dominated) and less quantity in the lower part (conduction dominated) would utilize natural convection more effectively. The temporal variation of stored energy for cylindrical and conical shaped LHSS is shown in Fig. 7. The conical shaped LHSS shows 7% more energy storage performance than a cylindrical LHSS due to faster melting. These findings are consistent with a recent experimental study [24] which shows an improved convective
heat flow in conical shaped LHSS.

sections.heading: 5.2. Effect of GNP dispersion in a conical LHSS (no fins)
sections.text:
This section investigates the proposed conical design with GNP inclusions. The effective thermal conductivity increases with the rise in the concentration of GNP inside the PCM. The rise in thermal conductivity is due to the combined effect of the nanoparticle aggregation, nonlocal and ballistic transport, thermophoresis and Brownian motion of the nanoparticles [18,40]. The enhanced conductivity improves the rate of heat transfer and shortens the overall melting time. The variation of the liquid fraction at different time intervals is shown in Fig. 8a. In the initial first hour (τ ≤ 1 h), the quantity of molten PCM is approximately the same for all the cases due to absorption of sensible heat from its initial temperature of 145 °C. The increased viscosity due to GNP dispersion slows down the movement of molten PCM and reduces the temperature gradient in the early phase of melting. However, as the
quantity of molten PCM rises, the combined effect of natural convection and enhanced thermal conductivity expedite the melting process. The contours of liquid fraction (left side) and isotherms (right side) are shown in Fig. 8b. It is observed that the melting interface develops more in the radial direction than in the axial direction due to the movement of liquid PCM towards the top region. At τ > 1 h, most of the PCM absorbs sufficient sensible heat and reaches its onset melting temperature. The melting interface starts to move in the downward axial direction due to the formation of circulating Benard convection cells under the influence of gravity and temperature gradient. The rise of GNP concentration accelerates the melting process due to increased thermal conduction, sufficient enough to surpass the negative effect of enhanced viscosity. The higher quantity of PCM is melted at 5% GNP as compared with 1% GNP concentration. It is observed that the shape of the melting interface is more irregular at this stage due to the noticeable effect of natural convection. The final stage of melting (τ > 3 h) is purely driven by convection as the maximum quantity of PCM is
already in the liquid state. The PCM is completely melted (red color) at GNP volume 5% after 5 h. However, there exists some solid PCM (blue color) in the bottom region at a lower concentration of GNP. The total melting time is reduced by 18%, 30% and 39% in a conical LHSS at a GNP volume fraction of 0.01, 0.03 & 0.05 respectively as compared with a conventional cylindrical LHSS.

sections.heading: 5.3. Combined effect of GNP and fins in conical shaped LHSS
sections.text:
The compound effect of using GNP and fins in a conical shaped LHSS is studied in this section. The temporal variation of liquid fraction in a finned conical LHSS with varying concentration of GNP is shown in Fig. 9a. The fins inside the PCM domain act as individual heat sources and diffuse heat quickly. The combined use of active and passive heat transfer techniques proposes a highly efficient LHSS with higher
charging/discharging rates. The melting time for the conical finned LHSS with 5% GNP is 3.4 h which shows a reduction of 57% in melting time. The melting time reduces by 46%, 47% and 53% at a GNP volume fraction of 0%, 1% & 3% respectively in a conical finned LHSS. The GNP dispersion also raises the viscosity and density of nano-PCM composite which severely deteriorates the convection heat transfer. It is concluded that conical LHSS with 1% GNP is not showing a substantial improvement in thermal performance. The total melting time of conical LHSS with GNP dispersion (0.01 vol%) is only reduced by 2.1% in comparison with an LHSS without GNP. Hence, there must be a tradeoff between the enhanced thermal conductivity and reduced natural convection while dispersing nanoparticles.
The contours of liquid fraction (left) and temperature (right) for a finned LHSS at different concentration of GNP are shown in Fig. 9b. In the initial melting phase (τ < 0.5 h), nano-PCM composite near the
heated pipe absorbs the sufficient sensible heat and reaches the onset temperature. At τ= 1 h, the influence of natural convection is pronounced as evident by the distortion of melting interface and temperature contour lines. Subsequently, in the later stages (τ > 2 h), molten PCM occupies the top region of LHSS due to buoyancy effect (under the influence of gravity). Fins diffuse heat quickly in the enhanced conductive nano-PCM composite packed in a conical design. The collective benefit of fins, GNP and conical shape proposes an effective LHSS design for quick charging rates.
The movement of liquid PCM is shown through the streamlines in Fig. 9c. The high velocity (red color) is observed near the heated pipe wall carrying HTF. Earlier onset of Benard convection cell gives rise to higher heat transfer rate due to enhanced intermixing of both cold and hot layers of fluid. Moreover, Benard cells rapidly appear in a vertical orientation (as compared with horizontal) walls which causes enhanced natural convection heat transfer [41]. Benard cells are formed between the fin spacing as fins are acting as individual heat sources. In the present work, it is found that these cells are increasing with time as more quantity of PCM is melted which further enhances the rate of heat
transfer. The heat flux variations and energy stored in a finned conical LHSS with GNP are discussed in the subsequent sections.

sections.heading: 5.3.1. Heat flux variations
sections.text: The temporal variation of average heat flux is presented in Fig. 10 for all the conical cases studied. Heat flux reduces quickly in the initial phase of conduction dominating the melting process. Subsequently, the heat flux is relatively constant due to the combined effect of convection & conduction. The GNP dispersion enhances the effective thermal conductivity of nano-PCM composite and increases the overall rate of heat transfer. Hence, the heat flux is more with a higher concentration of GNP. It is quite evident that fin addition restricts the natural convection heat transfer. Therefore, heat flux drops more quickly in an LHSS with fins (and GNP) as compared with an LHSS with GNP only. Nevertheless, fins act as an individual heat source inside the PCM and disperse heat more quickly. In the final melting stage, heat flux falls quickly because of weak conduction and heat transfer is predominantly governed by convection.

sections.heading: 5.3.2. Energy stored
sections.text:

Initially, sensible heat is stored until the PCM attains the temperature of 164 °C. After that, the latent heat is absorbed due to the melting of PCM. The sensible, latent and total heat absorbed is 0.87 MJ, 2.6 MJ and 3.5 MJ respectively in 3.45 h. It is seen that 75% of total heat is stored as latent heat and rest 25% as sensible energy. The finned conical design with GNP provides a highly efficient storage system with a capacity of 1 MJ/h.

The melt enhancement ratio is plotted against time as shown in Fig. 12. It is observed that a combination of fins and GNP gives the highest melt enhancement ratio. Fins diffuse heat quickly in the PCM domain and thereby increases the amount of melted PCM. The enhancement ratio for a finned conical LHSS with GNP is 45%, which is much higher than the conical LHSS without fins. In the initial 3 h, melt ratio rises rapidly due to the combined effect of fins and highly conductive GNP. However, conical LHSS with only 1% GNP shows the negative ratio, which reflects the melting rate is faster for the base case. The reason for this negative ratio is that the increased thermal conductivity due to 1% GNP is not sufficient to surpass the increased viscosity, which further restricts the natural convection heat transfer. The conical shape of LHSS counteracts the adverse effect of adding GNP by improving convective heat transport. Further, fin addition in the GNP dispersed PCM packed in conical shell proposes a highly efficient LHSS for quick charging rates.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
The present research proposes a highly efficient LHSS with conical shape comprising fins and GNP for the multistage solar cooling system, using a medium temperature PCM. The adverse effects of using fins and nanoparticles can be suppressed using an optimized fin with nanoparticles together in a conical shaped LHSS. The reduction of 57% in the melting time significantly enhances the overall charging performance. It is concluded that;
• CuO, SiO2, and TiO2 are not suitable candidates for designing a quick charging solar cooling storage system. • Combined MADM and MODM ranking methodology predict graphene as the best candidate followed by aluminum and alumina. Graphene shows the highest rise in thermal conductivity and minimum reduction in specific & latent heat. • Conical LHSS makes use of natural convection advantageously by packing more PCM quantity in the upper region. A reduction of 16% in the melting time is observed with conical LHSS. • Employing fins in the conical LHSS provide better heat transfer enhancement than the nanoparticles dispersion. • Finned TES with 1% GNP doesn’t show substantial improvement in thermal performance due to enhanced viscosity and restriction of
natural convection vortices.
The proposed design employing both active and passive heat transfer enhancement techniques can be scaled up to any desired capacity. The present work would be helpful in designing any medium temperature (150–200 °C) vertical LHSS for quick charging/discharging rates.

metadata.abstractText: This study introduces a novel latent heat storage system using a combination of active (fins and nanoparticles) and passive (conical design) heat transfer enhancement techniques for the solar absorption chilling system. First part of the work proposes a selection criterion using Multi-attribute decision making (MADM) combined with Multi objectives decision making (MODM) tools to rank and select the different nanoparticles. The methodology suggests Graphene as the best candidate amongst the widely used metal (Cu, Al, Ni, Ag) and metal oxide (CuO, Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2) nanoparticles. Subsequently, the charging performance of the medium temperature eutectic salt (LiNO3-KCl; 50:50) dispersed with graphene nanoplates is studied in a conical shaped shell and tube storage system with & without fins. The numerical investigations are performed using the actual plant data of double effect solar absorption system. Based on the plant operating conditions, the Stefan and Grashoff numbers are obtained as 0.35 & 4.2 × 105 respectively, showing the laminar flow of molten PCM. The thermal performance of the storage system coupled with heat transfer and fluid flow is studied for melt fraction, temperature field, the energy stored and heat flux variations at different concentration of graphene. Effect of enhanced viscosity and reduction in natural convection heat transfer due to GNP dispersion is studied simultaneously with the gained advantage of increased thermal conductivity. It is concluded that melting time is reduced by 57% using the proposed storage design in comparison with a conventional cylindrical system.
